dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Alright, so, um, the Biden-Xi summit in San Francisco recently, right? There were, like, some pretty notable outcomes.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Alright, so, um, the Biden-Xi summit in San Francisco recently, right? There were, like, some pretty notable outcomes.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: US President Joe Biden and Chinese President Xi Jinpings San Francisco sum... Notably, the two countries will resume military-to-military communication...

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, for sure. I mean, the big ones were, uh, they're resuming military-to-military communication, which is huge for, you know, reducing accidental conflicts. And then China's gonna step up on restricting fentanyl chemical exports, which is a major issue here.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, for sure. I mean, the big ones were, uh, they're resuming military-to-military communication, which is huge for, you know, reducing accidental conflicts. And then China's gonna step up on restricting fentanyl chemical exports, which is a major issue here.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Notably, the two countries will resume military-to-military communication, thereby reducing the chances of an accidental conflict, and China will do more to restrict the export of chemicals used to make the powerful synthetic opioid fentanyl a major cause of death in the United States.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Right, those are definitely, like, positive steps. But, uh, there was one *major* area where they just... didn't make any progress at all, it seems. And that was tariffs.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right, those are definitely, like, positive steps. But, uh, there was one major area where they just... didn't make any progress at all, it seems. And that was tariffs.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: But there is one crucial area where progress remained elusive: tariffs.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Oh, God, the tariffs. It's such a sticky one. I mean, it all goes back to, what, 2018? When Trump's administration just dramatically hiked tariffs on Chinese imports, from like, barely over 3% to *over 21%*. It's pretty wild.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Oh, God, the tariffs. It's such a sticky one. I mean, it all goes back to, what, twenty eighteen? When Trump's administration just dramatically hiked tariffs on Chinese imports, from like, barely over three percent to over twenty one percent. It's pretty wild.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: In 2018, then-US President Donald Trumps administration hiked the tariff rate on imports from China from slightly over 3% to more than 21%

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, a level we hadn't seen since before World War I, apparently. And, of course, China retaliated, slapping their own tariffs on US goods.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, a level we hadn't seen since before World War I, apparently. And, of course, China retaliated, slapping their own tariffs on U S goods.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: a level unseen in the US since before World War II.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly. And then it just spiraled, you know? The article even points out that China lowered tariffs on other countries, making European goods, like, less competitive in their market. It's a mess.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly. And then it just spiraled, you know? The article even points out that China lowered tariffs on other countries, making European goods, like, less competitive in their market. It's a mess.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: As China also lowered its tariffs on imports from all other countries, it reduced the competitiveness of US goods in the Chinese market by an even greater amount.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: And the WTO, um, actually ruled against the US tariffs in 2020, saying they're incompatible with global trade rules. So, we're kind of undermining the system.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And the W T O, um, actually ruled against the U S tariffs in twenty twenty, saying they're incompatible with global trade rules. So, we're kind of undermining the system.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: In any case, a WTO panel ruled in 2020 that the Trump tariffs are incompatible with Americas legal obligation to abide by the organizations rules.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Totally. But here's the thing: who's actually paying for these tariffs? Because, like, every serious study shows those increased costs are passed directly onto American consumers.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Totally. But here's the thing: who's actually paying for these tariffs? Because, like, every serious study shows those increased costs are passed directly onto American consumers.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Every serious study of the issue suggests that the increased costs arising from the tariffs have been passed onto American consumers.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Right! I mean, if we just removed them, the cost of our household consumption basket could drop by over half a percentage point. But that's just the start.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right! I mean, if we just removed them, the cost of our household consumption basket could drop by over half a percentage point. But that's just the start.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Since imported goods account for about 12% of the US household-consumption basket, the removal of the Trump tariffs would lower the cost of that basket by about half a percentage point.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: [interrupts] Exactly! Because, like, almost half of our imports from China are parts and components for American manufacturers. So, if those tariffs went away, input costs for *our* businesses would drop, too.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly! Because, like, almost half of our imports from China are parts and components for American manufacturers. So, if those tariffs went away, input costs for our businesses would drop, too.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: About 40% of US imports from China are parts, components, and intermediate goods, so removing the Trump tariffs would also lower input costs for American service providers and manufacturers.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Which means prices for American-made goods would also decline. And then there are, like, the indirect effects of increased competition. Cheaper Chinese goods mean other countries, like Mexico or Vietnam, have to lower their prices too.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Which means prices for American-made goods would also decline. And then there are, like, the indirect effects of increased competition. Cheaper Chinese goods mean other countries, like Mexico or Vietnam, have to lower their prices too.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: As a result, the prices of many American-made products and services in the US household-consumption basket would also decline. Then there are the indirect effects. As Chinese imports become cheaper, competitive pressure on other producers would rise, leading to lower prices on goods made in Mexico, India, Vietnam, and even the US.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, it's a ripple effect. The article says, combined, all these things could permanently reduce the cost of living for Americans by, like, one and a half percentage points. That's huge!
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, it's a ripple effect. The article says, combined, all these things could permanently reduce the cost of living for Americans by, like, one and a half percentage points. That's huge!
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Taken together, these effects would permanently reduce the cost of living to Americans by about one percentage point.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: That's like an extra $300 billion in US household income per year. So, it really begs the question, why aren't they doing this? US firms would benefit too, if China removed its retaliatory tariffs.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: That's like an extra three hundred billion dollars in U S household income per year. So, it really begs the question, why aren't they doing this? U S firms would benefit too, if China removed its retaliatory tariffs.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Put another way, this would be equivalent of an increase in US household income by more than $250 billion per year (1% of US GDP in 2022).

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: I know! And Biden could really use a political win right now. Voters are, um, really concerned about the rising cost of living. His approval numbers aren't great.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: I know! And Biden could really use a political win right now. Voters are, um, really concerned about the rising cost of living. His approval numbers aren't great.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Biden is facing a highly contentious election next year, and the rising cost of living is voters number one economic concern. In a recent poll, just 14% of American voters reported being better off financially now than when Biden took office.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: So, what's the hang-up? Is it just that he doesn't want to give Republicans ammunition to say he's 'soft on China'?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So, what's the hang-up? Is it just that he doesn't want to give Republicans ammunition to say he's 'soft on China'?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: It is said that Biden does not want to give the Republicans a reason to say that he is soft on China.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: That's what it seems like. But, honestly, the article really drives home the point that not communicating these potential benefits to voters, um, it's a failure of leadership. It's a huge missed opportunity.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: That's what it seems like. But, honestly, the article really drives home the point that not communicating these potential benefits to voters, um, it's a failure of leadership. It's a huge missed opportunity.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: But he should communicate to voters that removing the Trump tariffs would be good for American households and firms. Not doing so is a failure of leadership.
